Higher derivatives

When we differentiate a function \(y=f(x)\), we get a value \(f'(x)\) at each point \(x\).  But that then is itself a function, \(g\), say: \(g(x) = f'(x)\) for all \(x\).  It is entirely possible that this function \(g\) is itself differentiable.  If so then we can form the second derivative of \(f\), \(f''\), or \(\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\), which is defined just by differentiating \(f'\): \[ \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2}= f''(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f'(x+h)-f'(x)}{h}. \] It is possible that we can then differentiate yet again to get the third derivative \(f''' \) or \(\dfrac{d^3 y}{dx^3}\).  In general we can consider finding the \(n\)th derivative \(f^{(n)}\) or \(\dfrac{d^n y}{dx^n}\). Calculating multiple higher derivatives do correspond to physical properties, so it is useful to be comfortable with higher derivatives. For example, in physics, the second derivative of position is acceleration.

Example

Find the second derivative of the function \(f(x) = 3 \sin (x)+ x^4  -x^2 -4x +2.\)

Solution

We calculate that \[f'(x) = 3 \cos(x) + 4 x^3 -2x-4\] and so \[f''(x) = -3\sin(x) + 12x^2 -2.\]
